sample.dialogue: PEDRO SPEAKS. And my opinion is,

forasmuch as euerye thing sheweth nowe a certaine
naturall amitie amongst themselues, yea, the trees, sayeth Plinie , hath a naturall instinct of friendship, the sweete flowers, the pleasaunt herbes, declares the same also, that we intreate somewhat of friendship, and bicause no friendship, or amitie is, or ought to be more deere, and surer, than the loue of man and wyfe, let thys treatise be thereof, wherein I woulde the duetie of the married man to be discribed. For the knowledge of duetie is the maintenance of friendship.
sample.nonSpeech: All the companie commended Maister Pedro for this pleasant deuise, & the Lady Iulia standing vp, sayd, that forsomuch, as the soueraignetie, though not with hir will, was committed vnto hir wyth consent of them all,
sample.dialogue: and due obedience promised, I like well,
of thys which Mayster Pedro hath alreadie deuised, touching friendship, and duetie of the maried man. Wherefore, by the same authoritie, which I haue receyued, I commaunde you Sir,
sample.nonSpeech: and turned hir towardes Maister Pedro ,
sample.dialogue:
to performe this charge, which you haue deuised of the maried man, not for that I thinke you to
be a better husbande, than any of the reast here. But because we being yet wholy ignorant in this kinde of pastimes, you may, as the principall authour thereof, instruct vs in the whole circumstance: and againe, being so well languaged, as you are, we shall haue good sporte, to heare you interlarde our Countrie speeche with some Spanishe trickes. PEDRO BEGINS HIS SPEECH ABOUT MARRIAGE WHICH HE CALLS THE FLOWER OF FRIENDSHIP: HE GIVES A HISTORICAL ACCOUNT OF MARRIAGE IN ANCIENT CULTURES: HE FINISHES WITH THE VENETIAN CUSTOM OF BUYING WIVES.
an vnhappie custome was it,

& likely that the Flower of Friendship was but weaklye rooted betweene them of so slender acquaintance, but I praye you tell vs, how the indifferent sorte were maried, that were neyther foule, nor fayre, but louely browne. Mary,
for such amongst the Venetians , there was no money either giuen, or taken, but were maried for naught. And so perchaunce,
sample.nonSpeech: quoth a merie gentleman, that stoode by, called Mayster Gualter of Cawne,
sample.dialogue: were some of the fairest, as they be sometimes nowe a dayes. I haue also read,

that in Fraunce, the maydens did choose their husbands in this sorte. The parents called a number of yong men to a banket, who~ they thought fittest, & him, to whom the mayde gaue first water, by that signe she chose for hir husband. In Mauritania , as sayeth Diodorus Siculus , there was such store of women, y=t= euery man might haue fiue wyfes, and no lesse than three, which also after y=e= death of their husbands,
within one moneth eyther wyllingly buried themselues with him, or were perforce executed by the lawe. In the Isles of Canaria , there were contrariwise so many men, and so fewe women, that euerie wife might haue seuen husbandes, & could not take lesse than fiue. But I trust,
that those men were not so kinde harted, as to be buried with their wyfes, as the women in that other countrie were with their husbandes. I thinke not,
and I doubt whether those women of Mauritania coulde not haue beene contented to haue taried behinde their husbandes, had there beene no lawe to haue compelled them. Tush

thys is farre fro~ your matter. PEDRO CONTINUES WITH CHALDEANS AND GREEKS: HE CONCLUDES THAT LOVE IN MARRIAGE MUST BE GIVEN TIME TO GROW LITTLE BY LITTLE.
Why?
shal a man choose his wyfe with his eares. To choose with our eares
is to enquire of hir vertues, & vices, by report whereof you shall vnderstande hir conditions, and qualities, good, & bad. As for that

it booteth SOURCE TEXT: booteh not. For the best of them all haue their faults, and if she be vertuous, she will looke to be so honored, that hir husband shall haue the more a do to please hir. And I remember, that a wise man, I knowe not hys name, being enquired of a friende of hys, with whome he should marry, aunswered, that he had beene married foure sundrie times, first with a fayre woman, who was so prowde of hir bewtie, that he was faine to please, and content hir, least she should dishonour him, the seconde verie riche, whose substance made hir so stately, that he was forced lyke a slaue to obey hir, the thirde was so vertuous, that he was glad
to honor, and reuerence hir, to keepe hir still in hir vertuous goodnesse, the last was of good lineage, which so exalted hir stomacke, that shee made him hir bondman. Nowe choose,
which of these foure thou canst best content thy self. You haue made a fayre reason,

I neuer knewe that you were so deepely learned before, PEDRO CONTINUES TO SPEAK ABOUT MARRIAGE GIVING EXAMPLES FROM THE BIBLE AND THE CLASSICS: HE CONCLUDES BY SAYING THAT THERE ARE MANY MORE INTERESTING EXAMPLES.
You haue yet day ynough,

Wherfore we pray you to shewe vs some of those examples for oure instruction. PEDRO CONTINUES WITH THE SAME: THERE ARE CERTAIN ACTIONS AND METHODS THAT SHOULD BE USED TO ACHIEVE A HAPPY MARRIAGE. PEDRO CALLS THESE ACTIONS "HERBS".
These be excellent herbes,

and rarely founde all in one garden. Wherefore we pray you teach vs, how we maye plant, and conserue them. PEDRO CONTINUES: HE CONCLUDES WITH THE ISSUE OF WOMEN AND SECRECY.
It is happie
that some women haue beene secret in times past. For you men say nowe a dayes, that women can keepe no counsaile. See I pray you,

how soone this Ladie, had gotten holde of that sentence, which so little serueth hir purpose. For I trust it was an easie matter for that woman to keepe silence, when shee wanted hir tongue. PEDRO CONTINUES ON THE SAME ISSUES.
I thanke you for this,
thys is the truest tale, you tolde to daye, and hitherto, you haue but flattered these Ladies. Not so,
For I spake nothing heretofore but the truth, neyther speake I this nowe generallye against all women. For that were slaunderous vnto them. I do but touch some shrewde wyues. Tushe,

they bee shrewes all, and if you giue the simplest of them leaue to daye to treade vpon your foote, to morrowe she will tread vpon thy head. PEDRO CONTINUES: SOLON SENTENCED A FATHER TO BE DEPRIVED OF HIS SEPULCHRE AFTER HIS DEATH BECAUSE OF HIS POOR UPBRINGING OF HIS SON: THE SON WAS DISINHERITED FOR DISOBEDIENCE.
I assure you,

that same was an excellent iudgement of the wise Solon , and if it were put in vse at these dayes, there woulde be many fathers to lye wythout graues, and as many sonnes put from their inheritance. The more pittie,

and I thought to haue sayde more therein. But the sunne is so much declined, that it is more then tyme to vnburden these Ladies of this tedious talke, and I feare me, I haue alreadye troubled them to long. Not so,
For sooner shoulde we want the day light, than good will to brace you, though the day were so long againe. You say your pleasure,

But nowe to knit vp this Flower of matrimoniall amitie, and friendshippe, touching the office of the man, I say, that hee must aboue all thinges haue the feare of God before his eyes, which with the rest well considered, and put in execution, no doubt hee shall enioye the flagrant fauour thereof. THE COMPANY THANKS PEDRO FOR HIS TALK: JULIA WANTS TO HEAR MORE: SHE GIVES HIM HER GARLAND.
JULIA SPEAKS. For I shall not bee in quiet,
till I haue hearde the married woman prescribed in lyke sorte, as you haue done the married man, neyther can this Flower well prosper, or bee perfite, except the woman also put to hir helping hande.
sample.nonSpeech: Whereto mayster Pedro aunswered, that in the woman was to be required great helpe for the preseruation of this friendlye Flower .
sample.dialogue: Yet will I not,

take the authoritie from you. But if you list to departe with it to some other, you shall your selfe to morrowe resigne it to whome it pleaseth you, PEDRO TELLS JULIA TO LEAVE THE GARLAND: THE COMPANY DECIDES TO MEET THE NEXT DAY.

dialogue.comment: ALOISA HAS ACCEPTED THE GARLAND AND NOW SPEAKS.

sample.dialogue:
I will that the Ladie Iulia doe briefely (for that the day is farre past) discribe vnto vs, the office, and duetie of the married woman, in lyke sort as mayster Pedro hath done for y=e= mans behalfe,
and therein to shew in what sort she must applie hir selfe, to maintaine this Flower of Friendship betweene hir husbande and hir. AFTER SOME HESITATION THE LADY JULIA BEGINS HER SPEECH ABOUT WOMEN'S DUTIES IN MARRIAGE: SHE DOES THIS IN THE SAME WAY AS PEDRO DID, GIVING EXAMPLES FROM THE CLASSICS: SHE TURNS TO GUALTER SAYING THAT THERE HAVE ALWAYS BEEN WOMEN AS LOVING AS MEN: GUALTER RESPONDS.
No doubt Madam,
ye loue passingly, when yee do loue, and you hate as extreemelye, when yee doe hate. Wherefore it were a goodly matter, if you coulde bring your married women vnto a meane. Not so,

I will haue no meane in loue. JULIA CONTINUES: SHE COMES TO THE ISSUE OF OBEDIENCE.
I know not,

what we are bounde to do, but as meete is it, that the husbande obey the wife, as the wife the husband, or at the least that there bee no superioritye betwene them, as the auncient philosophers haue defended. For women haue soules as wel as men, they haue wit as wel as men, and more apte for procreation of children, than men. What reason is it then, that they should be bound, whome nature hath made free? Naye, among the Achaians , wome~ had such soueraigntie, that whatsoeuer they commaunded, their Husbandes obeyed. Yea, Plutarch saith, that the man swept the house, drest the meate, and did all other necessaries, where the woman gouerning the house, and keping the money, aunswered all matters, and which woorse was, they corrected them at their discretio~.
What did shee,

& might she beate him too? Mary lo. Here is the matter, that some of our Dames in this Countrie take so much vppon them. They think belike that they be in Achaia . But sure if I had bene amongst those women: you would haue done,
sample.nonSpeech: quoth the Ladie Isabella SOURCE TEXT: Isablla ,
sample.dialogue: as they did. For Dogs barke boldely at their owne maisters doore. Beleue not daughter,

neither those ignorant Philosophers, nor these fonde customes. For contrary also to this, the Parthians , & Thracians accounted not of their wiues, more than of slaues, so that after they had borne them a dosen children, or more, they sold the mothers at the common markets, or exchaunged them for yonger. Fye vpon that law,
But what saye you to the custome which Dionysius Alicarnasseus , wryteth of the Numidians and Lydians , where the woman commaunded within doores, and the men without. Yea marie
that was a iust law, where the commau~ding was equall. Not so,

For though
it were better than the other two: yet not tollerable amongst vs, neyther was the soueraignetie so equallye deuided, as you thinke. For if the woma~ keepe alwaies hir house, as duetie is, the man standeth euer at hir comaundement. For as long as she is within, though he commaund hir without, this lawe byndeth hir not to obey. Wherefore in my opinion al those Barbarian customes are to be disanulled, and co~temned of Christians. Ye say well, Madam,
For in deede both diuine, & humaine lawes, in our religion giueth the man absolute authoritie, ouer the woman in all places. And,

as I sayde before, reason doth confirme the same, the man being as he is, most apt for the soueraignetie being in gouernement, not onely skill, and experience to be required, but also capacity to comprehende, wisdome to vnderstand, strength to execute, solicitude to prosecute, pacience to suffer, meanes to sustaine, and aboue all a great courage to accomplishe, all which are commonly in a man, but in a woman verye rare: Then what blame deserue
those men that doe permit their wyues to rule all, and suffer themselues to be commaunded for company. A hard aduenture,

hapneth to that man, which is matched with a maisterly shrew. For she being once past shame, not onely blabbeth out all, that she knoweth, but thundereth oute that also, which hir mad head conceyueth, or hir fantasticall braine dreameth of, and yet will she maintaine, that she is neuer angrie, or speaketh without great cause. JULIA CONTINUES: THE WOMAN MUST BE ABLE TO SEE THE MOOD OF HER HUSBAND BY THE LOOK ON HIS FACE.
Why,
what if he bee mad, or dronke, must we then shew the like countenance. If you perceiue him in such case,

speake him fayre, and flatter him, till you get hym to bed. and there reprehende him louingly, with
kissing and imbrasing, that he maye perceyue it to come of pure loue, more than of malice, for better were it to conuert him louingly in gentlenesse, than to controle him frowardly in shrewdnesse. It is most true,

For in this point, we are not muche vnlyke to wylde and sauage beasts, as the lyon, or the vnicorne, which by the force can not bee tamed, but by humilitie, and gentle meanes, so that who will reclayme vs, must auoyde all contrarying, and veration of minde, whereof I could tell you a pretie story, that of late yeares happened to a gentlewoma~, that by suche gentle wyles reclaymed hir husband, being farre gone, but I shoulde iniurie the Lady Iulia , to entermeddle so farre in hir charge. Not so,

but you shall greatly pleasure mee therein, wherfore I pray you let vs heare it. PEDRO TELLS THE STORY OF THE WOMAN WHO RECLAIMED HER HUSBAND.
He should,
haue had a bed of nettles, or thornes, had it bene to mee. For sure I would not haue beene the cherisher of my husband in his vnthriftinesse. And so should you haue made him worse,

THE DISCUSSION IS CONCLUDED: THE LADY ISABELLA ASKS THE AUTHOR TO WRITE IT DOWN WITH THESE WORDS.
For
your quiet silence both these dayes, assureth mee, that you haue well considered thereof,
sample.nonSpeech: and therewith the reast of the ladies joyned with her, at whose importunate request, with the helpe of my friend Maister Pedro , and others, I haue aduentured to publishe this Discourse.
